Macros
new
new(
type
)

New is a function-macro that, given a type, creates a new object of that type.

The constructor is supplied by the given object type. This means that in order for this macro to work a constructor function with the following signature must be defined in the types Class struct.

void constructor(void *obj)

Note that the naming convention of <type> for objects of class <type>_t must be followed in order for this macro expansion to work properly. An example of this naming convention is a string. The object is a String struct and the class associated with that object is a String_t struct.

Note that the struct of <type>_t must contain a Class struct as a member named "class" in order for this macro expansion to work properly. The Class struct defines how objects of <type> are created, destroyed, copied, and compared. An example of this is the String_t struct.

copy
copy(
type,
obj
)

Copy is a function-macro that, given a type and a preexisting object, creates a copy of the object.

The copyConstructor is supplied by the given object type. This means that in order for this macro to work a copyConstructor function with the following signature must be defined in the types Class struct.

void* copyConstructor(void *obj, const void * const other, size_t size)

Note that the naming convention of <type> for objects of class <type>_t must be followed in order for this macro expansion to work properly. An example of this naming convention is a string. The object is a String struct and the class associated with that object is a String_t struct.

Note that the struct of <type>_t must contain a Class struct as a member named "class" in order for this macro expansion to work properly. The Class struct defines how objects of <type> are created, destroyed, copied, and compared. An example of this is the String_t struct.

delete
delete(
type,
obj
)

Delete is a function-macro that, given a type and a preexisting object, deletes the object.

The destructor is supplied by the given object type. This means that in order for this macro to work a destructor function with the following signature must be defined in the types Class struct.

void destructor(void *obj)

Note that the naming convention of <type> for objects of class <type>_t must be followed in order for this macro expansion to work properly. An example of this naming convention is a string. The object is a String struct and the class associated with that object is a String_t struct.

Note that the struct of <type>_t must contain a Class struct as a member named "class" in order for this macro expansion to work properly. The Class struct defines how objects of <type> are created, destroyed, copied, and compared. An example of this is the String_t struct.

equals
equals(
type,
obj1,
obj2
)

Equals is a function-macro that, given a type and a preexisting object, compares the two objects. The return value is defined by the implementation of the comparator in the <type>_t struct.

The comparator is supplied by the given object type. This means that in order for this macro to work a comparator function with the following signature must be defined in the types Class struct.

int comparator(const void *first, const void *second, size_t size)

Note that the naming convention of <type> for objects of class <type>_t must be followed in order for this macro expansion to work properly. An example of this naming convention is a string. The object is a String struct and the class associated with that object is a String_t struct.

Note that the struct of <type>_t must contain a Class struct as a member named "class" in order for this macro expansion to work properly. The Class struct defines how objects of <type> are created, destroyed, copied, and compared. An example of this is the String_t struct.

DEFAULT_CLASS
DEFAULT_CLASS {
.allocator = malloc,
.constructor = constructor,
.copyConstructor = memcpy,
.destructor = destructor,
.equals = memcmp,
}

DEFAULT_CLASS is a macro that defines default allocator, copyConstructor, and equals functions.

The default allocator is malloc, the default copyConstructor is memcpy, and the default equals function is memcmp. All of these can be overridden manually.

A default constructor and destructor are NOT supplied. These functions need to be defined in the source file that the DEFAULT_CLASS macro expands in, and are assumed to have the following signatures and names:

void constructor(void *obj);
void destructor(void *obj);
Class
typedef struct
Class

The struct that defines various memory related operations related to objects.  Each struct of <type>_t needs to have a Class struct named "class" for the above macros to work.

Functions
allocator
void* (
*allocator
)(size_t size)

Responsible for allocating space for the object.

Parameters
size

The size in bytes to allocate for the object.

Returns

A void pointer to the memory block allocated.

constructor
void (
*constructor
)(void *obj)

Responsible for initializing an already allocated object.

Parameters
obj

A pointer to the memory block allocated for the object.

Returns

Nothing

copyConstructor
void* (
*copyConstructor
)(void *obj, const void * const other, size_t size)

Responsible for creating a clone of another object.

Parameters
obj

A pointer to the memory block allocated for the new object.

other

The object to copy.

size

The size of the object being copied.

Returns

A void pointer to the initialized new object.

destructor
void (
*destructor
)(void *obj)

Responsible for deleting and freeing memory allocated for the given object.

Parameters
obj

A pointer to the object.

Returns

Nothing

comparator
int (
*comparator
)(const void *first, const void *second, size_t size)

Responsible for comparing two objects of the same type.

Parameters
first

The first object to compare.

second

The second object to compare.

size

The size of the objects being compared.

Returns

The return value is defined by the implementation of the comparator in the <type>_t struct.
